channel.title: Detailed Hello World=Vb
channel.description:
Okay, im using 2005 so coding will be diffrent for 6.
First open visual basics, create a new application.
Double click on Form1.
You will now see
[code] Public Class Form1
Private Sub Form1_Load(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles MyBase.Load
End Sub End Class [/code]
Ok the.. [code] Public Class Form1 [/code] Is telling you the class, it always puts the name of your project you picked.
[code] Private Sub Form1_Load(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles MyBase.Load [/code] That is creating the whole windows application and loading it.
[code] End Sub [/code] This will end the Form1_Load and anything else under it.
[code] End Class [/code] Simple, its ending the Form1 Public Class.
Now to begin..
Add this after the sub [code] MessageBox.Show("Hello World!") [/code]
So it would look like.. [code] Public Class Form1
Private Sub Form1_Load(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles MyBase.Load MessageBox.Show("Hello World!") End Sub End Class [/code]
The MessageBox is going to open a new window (application).
.Show is going to make it appear.
The ("Hello World!") is going to display the text "Hello World!", so whatever is between the quotes will be displayed.
You can also make it so where the Hello World pops up after you click a button.
Click the toolbox icon and drag a button onto your application.
Now double click on the button and add this [code] MessageBox.Show("Hello World!") [/code] So it would be.. [code] Public Class Form1
Private Sub Form1_Load(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles MyBase.Load End Sub
Private Sub Button1_Click(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles Button1.Click MessageBox.Show("Hello World!") End Sub End Class [/code]

item.title: Detailed Hello World=Vb
item.dc:creator: @usernamelol .Fusion
item.description:
@usernamelol wrote:

Okay, im using 2005 so coding will be diffrent for 6.

First open visual basics, create a new application.

Double click on Form1.

You will now see

Public Class Form1

	Private Sub Form1_Load(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles MyBase.Load

	End Sub
End Class

Ok the…

Public Class Form1

Is telling you the class, it always puts the name of your project you picked.

Private Sub Form1_Load(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles MyBase.Load

That is creating the whole windows application and loading it.

End Sub

This will end the Form1_Load and anything else under it.

End Class

Simple, its ending the Form1 Public Class.

Now to begin…

Add this after the sub

MessageBox.Show("Hello World!")

So it would look like…

Public Class Form1

	Private Sub Form1_Load(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles MyBase.Load
		MessageBox.Show("Hello World!")
	End Sub
End Class

The MessageBox is going to open a new window (application).

.Show is going to make it appear.

The (“Hello World!”) is going to display the text “Hello World!”, so whatever is between the quotes will be displayed.

You can also make it so where the Hello World pops up after you click a button.

Click the toolbox icon and drag a button onto your application.

Now double click on the button and add this

		MessageBox.Show("Hello World!")

So it would be…

Public Class Form1

	Private Sub Form1_Load(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles MyBase.Load
	End Sub

	Private Sub Button1_Click(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles Button1.Click
		MessageBox.Show("Hello World!")
	End Sub
End Class

Read full topic
